title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, 25 june [1868]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 25 June [1868]
text: â€”1868 BrooklynJune 25dear Walti received your letter to day thursdayThursday with the money all right i thought it was a goner as i didentdidn't get it yesterday i couldentcouldn't hardleyhardly give it up yesterday as you wrote in your fridaysFriday's letter i would get your letter on wensdayWednesday but it come to day very welcomemrMr.BurrousBurroughs has not been to see me i was exspectingexpecting him every day after you wrote but he didentdidn't come) i have not heard from jeffJeff nor mattyMatty since i wrote last to you) eddEdd said the letter man asked him to day why his mother didentdidn't get any more letters i used to get so many mattyMatty used to write quite often and Jeffy once in a while but they have all seemed to fall off) but the good old standby if he should fail me i should have nothing to look for but i gessguess there is no danger is there walterWalter dear as long as you have your old mamma i often think how loth many is to have children and what would become of me if i had none Janey mc clureMcClure that is nanc sNancy's brothersbrother's wife was here the other day she came to see if cornellCornell had been to see me about the children she sends them the most saucy letters they think if they should doodo any thinkthing she would not be any too good to kill her brother Edd thatsthat's the one in the new court house) i have come to the conclusion there is but one way to doodo and that is to send them to the nursery to flatbushFlatbush there is no institution in the city that they would be taken as they are janeyJaney thinks that is the only place that she couldentcouldn't get them out i cantcan't begin to tell and i dontdon't want too half the worse that wrechedwretched woman does i dontdon't know walterWalter how you feel about their being taken there but i know that i should feel much better than to have them sent out begging it would be no disgrace as there is many there that is of good parentage there they would be clothed and fed if they ever can be cleaned janeyJaney says thethey are so dirty that you would not know they were ever cleangood bie walterWalter dearyour motheri am about the same as usual feel quite smart at timesthey are digging the cellar at georgesGeorge's lot he had it survayedsurveyed yesterday Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 25 June [1868]
